Tony Smith ) took the chair at 10:00, made an acknowledgement of country and read prayers.

DOCUMENTS
Parliament House
Presentation

The SPEAKER (10:01): I present the Presiding Officer's statement regarding the condition of Parliament House. I'd also like to inform members that the installation of the turnstile on the stairs from Parliament Drive will progress in the near future. The President and I did not wish for this work element to proceed until our entrances had been completed. The turnstiles will operate in a free-spin mode for the time being. The timings for the implementation of the access control requiring passes is yet to be determined, but I'll keep members informed as we go.
COMMITTEES
Petitions Committee
Report
Mr LLEW O'BRIEN (Wide Bay) (10:02): I present the fifth report of the Petitions Committee for the 46th Parliament.
PETITIONS
Mr LLEW O'BRIEN (Wide Bay) (10:04): I present the following petitions:
Death Penalty

The people of Australia want justice for our nations most innocent: Its children. Pedophiles in this nation are let off with menial sentences, this tells the people that taking the innocence of a child away means nothing to the government. Many sexual abuse, and statutory rape cases never make it to court, and of those that do the average sentences are less than a year.
We want to send a message that we love our children and will stand firmly against pedophilia, we will not enable it! Death is the proportional penalty.
We therefore ask the House to repeal all legislation that prevents State Governments from implementing the Death Penalty as the punishment for pedophilia related crimes.
from 243 citizens (Petition No. EN1045)
Migraine

Migraine is one of the most debilitating conditions in Australia, estimated to affect nearly five million Australians, and cost the Australian economy $35 billion per year (Deloitte Access Economics 2018). However, very little is known about migraine prevalence and management in Australia, nor its real impact on the economy, welfare and health systems, education, business and employment, or on the quality of life for Australians living with migraine and their families.

We therefore ask the House to request an inquiry, to be conducted by an appropriate standing or select committee, into migraine, its management, and the burden of migraine on Australia; what is currently being done to alleviate that burden; and, what more can be done by Government and others to alleviate the burden of migraine in Australia.
from 1303 citizens (Petition No. EN1046)
Indigenous Health
We, the undersigned, say; we appeal to you to provide funding for the building of a South West Aboriginal Medical Service (SWAMS) Health Hub in Bunbury WA.

We have outgrown our current buildings and are not able to offer many programs, hire additional staff or offer our clients some of the care they deserve simply due to space constraints. This Health Hub will enable SWAMS to provide all of their medical services from one location; improving quality of life, access to community health and well-being services which is directly contributing to Closing the Gap for the Noongar people of the South West.

This planned facility will provide important services to our local community that we are currently unable to deliver due to space constraints. Services such as, mental health, alcohol and drug programs, social and emotional well-being and healthy lifestyle programs. This facility will house a community and well-being centre and create a space for cultural connections and healing. The Health Hub will allow us to bring a wide variety of cultural, community and well-being services to our region. By incorporating unique cultural themes into these endeavours and activities, we will empower and encourage positive social impact, self-determination and active participation for our local Noongar community.
We therefore ask the House to provide funding for the building of a South West Aboriginal Medical Service (SWAMS) Health Hub in Bunbury WA.
from 494 citizens (Petition No. EN1047)
Temporary Protection Visas
Protection Visa
"It is now absolutely clear that any Hong Kong resident currently in Australia faces a genuine risk of harm should they return home," Senator Di Natale said.
"We have a legal and a moral obligation to offer them safe haven, and that is what Scott Morrison must order his government to do."

The Victorian senator said former prime minister Bob Hawke's decision to grant protection to Chinese citizens in the wake of 1989's Tiananmen Square massacre was a "shining example of Australian leadership in the world" which had made Australia a richer multicultural nation.
The 71-year-old was among the tens of thousands of Chinese students granted asylum in Australia by the former Labor prime minister after the 1989 Tiananmen Square massacre.
Why Chinese and Hong Kong students clash in Australia
As we can see the CCP support of the recent wave of pro-China demonstrators clashing with Hong Kong pro-democracy protesters in Australia.

Many Pro-Hong Kong Student once returning to Hongkong will face arrest, political persecution, unfair treatment and even personal injury. Even they show support in social media platform that countless people are intimidated by the CCP who have party organizations and threats to their lives.

We therefore ask the House to consider granting the permanent residency to the Hong Kong expat currently residing in Australia. I have a report on the asylum seekers for your review upon request. It contains analysis on the background of these people, the advantage of acceptance & the national impact.
from 441 citizens (Petition No. EN1048)
Broadband

NBNCo request to Tax Streaming services such as Netflix, YouTube would violate their obligation to Service as a layer 2 network provider. To Differentiate between data and video streaming they would have to operate at Layer 4 or above of the Network OSI model. This would give them access to the TCP/UDP packets meaning they would have control and access to all information sent and received from all Australians to their destinations. This would include emails, websites and online transactions. The New Tax would inflict expense to Students, Nurses or any profession furthering the education. What else do they want to Monetize? Tax Music, VOIP, vpn traffic. Data scraping and selling to Marketing Organisations. Manipulating data such as Blocking sites or monitoring data to specific countries. If deemed worthy to. Security of information, if they have access to Layer 4 data, this would make them A high target for Hackers. A single point of entry for all information sent and received in Australia. If they choose to offload the work to the lowest bidder and it goes overseas all our data would be available to a foreign Country. If they sell the company who would know Where the data would end up and what they would do with the Data, they collect.
We therefore ask the House to Stop NBNCo from Implementing the Streaming Tax Stop NBNCo from Conducting Business in any OSI Network Layer other than Layer 2.
from 293 citizens (Petition No. EN1051)
China: Organ Transplants

This petition of local residents and business owners in the electorate of lndi, draws to the attention of the House the recent final judgment and report from the independent China Tribunal chaired by Sir Geoffrey Nice QC stating that forced organ harvesting has been committed for years throughout China on a significant scale and that Falun Gong practitioners have been one - and probably the main - source of organ supply.

We therefore ask the House to: 1) support a resolution condemning the forced organ harvesting of the Falun Gong people and other prisoners of conscience in China 2) to support an introduction of a bill to discourage Australian citizens from travelling to China for organ transplants until such time that there can be evidence that no organs have been taken by force against the will of the donor.
from 25 citizens (Petition No. PN0439)
China: Organ Transplants

This petition of local residents and business owners in the electorate of Mallee, draws to the attention of the House the recent final judgment and report from the independent China Tribunal chaired by Sir Geoffrey Nice QC stating that forced organ harvesting has been committed for years throughout China on a significant scale and that Falun Gong practitioners have been one - and probably the main - source of organ supply.

We therefore ask the House to: 1) support a resolution condemning the forced organ harvesting of the Falun Gong people and other prisoners of conscience in China 2) to support an introduction of a bill to discourage Australian citizens from travelling to China for organ transplants until such time that there can be evidence that no organs have been taken by force against the will of the donor.
from 49 citizens (Petition No. PN0440)
PETITIONS
Responses
Mr LLEW O'BRIEN (Wide Bay) (10:04): I present the following ministerial responses to petitions previously presented:
Telecommunications
Dear Mr Magrathea

Thank you for your email of 10 October 2018 to the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Infrastructure, Transport and Regional Development, the Hon Michael McCormack MP, regarding an idea to stop mobile phone use in motor vehicles. The Deputy Prime Minister has asked me to respond on his behalf.
Road safety remains a priority for the Australian Government and we are committed to reducing the number of deaths and serious injuries caused by road crashes.

Thank you for your idea regarding the use of sound detection software in mobile phones and mobile devices. The Deputy Prime Minister acknowledges your petition and shares your concerns about the potential sources of distraction for drivers such as mobile phones and mobile devices. In recent years, police and state and territory road safety ministers have raised particular concerns about the rapid increase in the use of mobile phones in vehicles among the general population, including their use for purposes unrelated to driving.

In May 2018 the Transport and Infrastructure Council (the Council) acknowledged the need for all levels of government to do more to address deaths and injuries on our roads and endorsed the new National Road Safety Action Plan for 2018-2020 (Action Plan). The Council includes the Government, state, territory and New Zealand ministers with responsibility for transport and infrastructure issues, as well as the Australian Local Government Association. The Council also supported a nationally coordinated project to develop best practice in addressing driver distraction particularly from mobile phones. Further information is available at www,transportinfrastructurecouncil.gov.au/communique.

The Action Plan calls on governments to work together to develop a holistic strategy to reduce driver distraction, considering enforcement, new and emerging technology and refining legislation. Further information about the Action Plan is available at www.roadsafety.gov.au/action-plan/2018-2020

In September 2017 the Government initiated an Inquiry into the National Road Safety Strategy (NRSS) 2011-2020 and appointed two independent experts to look closely at the evidence and provide advice on how governments can work together to take stronger and more effective actions to enhance road safety and reduce road trauma.

On 12 September 2018, the Deputy Prime Minister welcomed the release of the NRSS Inquiry report. The Government will be carefully considering the recommendations of the report, which cover a wide range of areas including road safety leadership, resourcing, performance monitoring and innovative technology. The Deputy Prime Minister will be considering a range of proposals as part of the Government's response to the Inquiry. The Government will also conduct a new review of National Road Safety Governance, which was one of the recommendations of the NRSS Inquiry report. Further information about the Inquiry and the national approach to road safety is available at www.roadsafety.gov.au.

If you have not already done so, you may also wish to raise your suggestion with the Hon Mark Bailey MP, the Queensland Minister for Transport and Main Roads, who can be contacted at transportandmainroads@ministerial.qld.gov.au.
Thank you for raising this matter and I trust this information is of assistance. Yours sincerely
Damian Callachor
Chief of Staff
Dear Mr O'Brien

Thank you for your letter of 5 August 2019 regarding Petition number EN0161, requesting investigation of the use of sound detection software in mobile devices which would turn off the device if vehicle engine noise is detected.

Mr Magrathea wrote to me on 10 October 2018 about this petition, noting the lack of response from the Communications portfolio. I have enclosed a copy of the response to Mr Magrathea from my Chief of Staff, Mr Damian Callachor.
Thank you for raising this matter and 1 trust this information is of assistance. Yours sincerely
from the Deputy Prime Minister, Michael McCormack(Petition No. EN0161)
Qualifications of Members
Dear Chair
Thank you for your letter of 10 September 2019, regarding a petition (EN0229) presented to the House of Representatives.

The petition calls for those parliamentarians, following rulings by the High Court, acting as the Court of Disputed Returns, found as being ineligible to serve in the Australian Parliament to repay all monies received in their role and for their pensions to be cancelled.

Consistent with previous cases where the High Court has ruled a parliamentarian ineligible, consideration was given to the potential debt to the Commonwealth that arises from past payment of salaries and allowances, and other costs of office.

The Department of Finance, the Independent Parliamentary Expenses Authority and the Department of the House of Representatives (for Members of the House) or Department of the Senate (for Senators) determined the appropriate action regarding each debt, pursuant to requirements in the Public Governance, Performance and Accountability Act 2013 (the PGPA Act).

Like everyone else who owes a debt to the Commonwealth, those former parliamentarians could apply for a debt waiver under section 63(1) of the PGPA Act. During the last parliament, waivers were recommended by independent officials and granted in particular cases because it was difficult for individuals to know at the time of nomination, based on how the law was previously understood, that they were ineligible. The relevant individuals were found to have performed public duties in good faith

While superannuation details of individual cases cannot be provided, it is a matter of public record that the individuals involved entered parliament after the new superannuation scheme came into effect.
As a result, none of these individuals would be entitled to a defined benefit pension from the Commonwealth in respect of their parliamentary service.
Kind regards
from the Minister for Finance,Senator Mathias Cormann(Petition No. EN0229)
Australian Constitution
Dear Mr O'Brien

Thank you for your letters of 5 and 20 August 2019 regarding petitions EN0230 and EN0239 respectively, requesting that an audit of compliance with s 44 of the Constitution be conducted. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

I am aware that this petition was originally presented on 15 August 2017, and that the Petitions Committee has not received a response to the referral of the petition to my predecessor. My department's searches indicate this correspondence was marked for no further action, in error. I apologise for the error, and the delay in responding.

Since the date the petition was initially presented, the legislative framework for Commonwealth elections has changed. Recently, the Electoral Legislation Amendment (Modernisation and Other Measures) Act 2019 was enacted. That Act changed, among other things, the candidate nominations process for elections by requiring prospective candidates for an election to complete a qualification checklist to demonstrate eligibility under s 44 of the Constitution. Additional documents are also required, in certain circumstances, to support claims made in the qualification checklist submitted with the nomination.

The qualification checklist and any supporting documents provided with the checklist are published on the Australian Electoral Commission's website as soon as practicable from the declaration of nominations, until 40 days after the return of the writs. That is, until a petition disputing the election can no longer be filed under Part XXII of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918. After the return of the writs for the election, checklists and additional documentation for successful candidates (those elected as Senators or members of the House of Representatives) will be tabled in Parliament. I note that the requirements in the Act will apply to future elections.

Resolutions were agreed in the House of Representatives on 4 December 2017 and the Senate on 13 November 2017 requiring parliamentarians to disclose information relating to their citizenship. Further, and in accordance with resolutions of the House of Representatives and the Senate on 4 April 2019 and 3 April 2019 respectively, the current Register of Members' qualifications and Register of Senators' qualifications under sections 44 and 45 of the Constitution were established and are published. The Register of Members' qualifications can be found here: https://www.aph.gov.au/Senators_and_Members/Members/Qualifications. The Register of Senators' qualifications can be found here:
https//www.aph.gov.au/Parliamentary_Business/Committees/Senate/Senators_Interests/RegisterQual46thparl.
Thank you for raising this matter with me. I hope this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Mr Porter(Petition Nos EN0230 and EN0239)
Taxation
Dear Mr O'Brien

Thank you for your correspondence of 5 August 2019, originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning Tax on AlcoholâPetition number; EN0250. Your correspondence has been referred to me as I have responsibility for this matter.

As beer is already taxed at rates significantly lower than other forms of alcohol, such as spirits and ready-to-drink (RID) beverages, standardising alcohol taxes across all alcohol products would likely increase prices of most beer and wine, and reduce prices of spirits and RTDs.

Since this petition was received, the Australian Government has implemented a number of measures to level the playing field for craft brewers. From 1 July 2019, the draught beer concessional rates were extended to beer stored in containers between eight and 48 litres, making them accessible to craft brewers who use smaller kegs. In addition, the excise refund scheme cap for brewers and distillers was increased from $30,000 to $100,000. The excise refund scheme allows brewers and distillers to claim 60 per cent of the excise they have paid up to the cap per financial year.

More generally, the Government is backing small and medium-sized businesses through tax relief and by increasing and expanding access to the instant asset write-off. The Government has increased the instant asset write-off threshold to $30,000 and expanded access to medium-sized businesses with an annual turnover of less than $50 million until 30 June 2020. The threshold applies on a per asset basis, so eligible businesses can instantly write off multiple assets. The Government's changes ensure that more businesses continue to benefit from the instant asset write-off as they grow, supporting them to invest in assets and build their business.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
from the Minister for Housing and Assistant Treasurer, Mr Michael Sukkar (Petition No. EN0250)
Disability Support Pension
Dear Mr O'Brien
Thank you for your letter of 5 August 2019 concerning Petition EN0381.
The Disability Support Pension (DSP) is an income support payment to individuals with permanent physical, intellectual and/or psychiatric impairments that prevent them from working.

DSP is only one element of a range of supports the Australian Government has in place for people with disability. A person with disability may be eligible for the National Disability Insurance Scheme (NDIS), concession cards and Commonwealth Rent Assistance. Anyone receiving DSP will automatically be issued a Pensioner Concession Card (PCC), which assists with the costs of health care and medicines.

The Government's long-term national health plan is to build the world's best health system, a system that is equitable, provides for financial risk protection, and is based on access to timely, affordable and high-quality essential health services for all. In 2019-20, the Government will provide $104 billion for the health system. This compares with the Commonwealth's health spending in 2012-13 of $75 billion. Over the next four years, health investment will total $435 billion. These funds are being invested in more services, new treatments, more medicines, increased support for hospitals, expanded rural health services, and breakthrough new medical research.
Thank you again for raising this matter with me. Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Families and Social Services, Senator Ruston (Petition No. EN0381)
Infant Formula
Dear Mr O'Brien,
Thank you for your letter of 5 August 2019, concerning Standing Committee on PetitionsâPetition no EN0399âbaby formula exports. My sincere apologies for the delay in responding.

The Department of Agriculture is responsible for the regulatory oversight of Australian made dairy products exported from Australia in accordance with the Export Control Act 1982 and its subordinate legislation. In line with this legislation, all shipments of Australian made infant formula exported in volumes of greater than ten kilograms per individual consignment must meet strict manufacturing and export requirements, and must be issued with a permit by my department prior to export.

The department currently believes the ten kilogram limit in place is suitable to control the volume of legally exported Australian made infant formula. As part of the government's current review of export legislation, due for implementation 2021, the department will seek views from industry and key stakeholders regarding the appropriateness of the current legislation.

Many popular infant formula brands for sale in Australia such as A2, Karricare and Aptimal, which are currently being purchased off the shelf and subsequently exported, are not Australian made and therefore fall outside the remit of the department. While the department is not responsible for regulating the export of products not manufactured in Australia, officers have worked closely with a number of key stakeholders including the larger supermarket chains, the Infant Nutritional Council of Australia, Dairy Australia and local manufacturers, to ensure there remains sufficient supply and availability of infant formula for Australian parents.

Noting Australian consumer concerns about this practice, and as a result of collaborative discussions, I understand supermarkets continue to work with their suppliers regarding stock levels and are enforcing limits on individual purchases. I also understand several companies have made their products available online to ensure supply.

The department continues to work collaboratively with cross border agencies to investigate allegations around exports of dairy products, including infant formula to China. The penalties in place under export legislation are considerable and where appropriate, include financial and penal provisions.

The issue of infant formula availability and suitable controls over the export of Australian made dairy products is a challenging issue. 1 believe both industry and the government share a common goal of providing a safe and high quality product for our domestic and international markets.

Further information about the export of infant formula can be found on the department's website http://www.agriculture.gov.au/export/controlled-goods/dairy, or by contacting Mr Shayne Daniels, Director of the Dairy Exports program from the department.
Thank you for taking the time to write to me on this issue.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Agriculture, Senator Bridget McKenzie (Petition No. EN0399)
Energy
Dear Mr O'Brien

Thank you for your letter to the Minister for the Environment, the Hon Sussan Ley MP, concerning petition EN0614 on increasing Australia's uptake of solar energy. I am responding as the responsible Minister.

Under the Liberal National Government, Australia has recorded the highest per capita level of investment in renewable energy in the world, and we have now met the Renewable Energy Target ahead of schedule. According to the most recent statistics, 5 per cent of Australia's total electricity generation was from solar last year.

Additionally, the Government's small-scale Renewable Energy Scheme has encouraged significant new small-scale renewable energy supply by helping households and businesses to install rooftop solar photovoltaic (PV) panels and solar hot water systems. As at 30 June 2019, more than 2.1 million rooftop solar PV panels and 1.1 million solar water heater systems had been installed under the scheme. Australia has the world's highest level of uptake of household solar panels, with one in five Australian households now having solar panels on their roof.
Thank you for the opportunity to respond to this petition.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Energy and Emissions Reduction, Mr Taylor(Petition No. EN0614)

subdebateinfo.title: Royal Commission into Misconduct in the Banking, Superannuation and Financial Services Industry

p.span: Royal Commission into Misconduct in the Banking, Superannuation and Financial Services Industry
Dear Mr O'Brien

Thank you for your correspondence originally directed to the Assistant Treasurer, concerning Petition Number: EN0656, request for a Government Consumer Protection Insurance. Your correspondence has been referred to me as I have responsibility for this matter.

The Government has committed to establishing an industry-funded, forward-looking compensation scheme of last resort (CSLR), as part of its response to the Royal Commission into Misconduct in the Banking, Superannuation and Financial Services Industry.

This commitment is an important step to building trust and confidence in the dispute resolution framework in the financial system and will ensure individual and small business consumers have confidence that when a dispute is determined in their favour compensation will be awarded, even if the financial firm becomes insolvent.

Under the proposed arrangements, the scheme will be established as part of the Australian Financial Complaints Authority (AFCA) and will extend beyond disputes in relation to personal financial advice failures. Key design features and eligibility requirements will be released in due course.
In line with the Government's Royal Commission Implementation Roadmap, legislation giving effect to the CSLR will be introduced by the end of 2020.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Superannuation, Financial Services and Financial Technology, Senator Hume(Petition No. EN0656)
Consumer Goods: Planned Obsolescence
Dear Mr O'Brien

Thank you for your correspondence of 5 August 2019 to the Assistant Treasurer, the Hon Michael Sukkar MP, regarding the petition EN0755 about stopping planned obsolescence and reducing e-waste. Your letter has been referred to me for response as Minister for the Environment.

In December 2018, all of Australia's environment ministers and the President of the Australian Local Government Association set a unified direction for waste by agreeing to a new National Waste Policy. The Policy identifies waste avoidance as a priority. It encourages efficient use, reuse and repair, and calls for products to be designed so that waste is minimised, that they are made to last and can be repaired, and the materials that are used to manufacture products are easily recovered for recycling.

The National Waste Policy also identifies product stewardship as a priority. This includes development and implementation of partnerships across government and business to ensure that the negative impacts of products are minimised, waste is avoided, and reuse, repair and recycling of products is maximised throughout their life cycle. All governments are now developing an Action Plan to implement the Policy, which will be considered at the next Meeting of Environment Ministers in November this year.

To support these objectives, the Government has committed $167 million to an Australian Recycling Investment Plan. This Plan includes $20 million for a new Product Stewardship Investment Fund to accelerate work on new industry-led recycling schemes, including electrical and electronic products.

This new Fund will build on the National Television and Computer Recycling Scheme set up by the Australian Government under the Product Stewardship Act 2011. This scheme works to provide households and small businesses with access to industry-funded collection and recycling services for televisions and computers, printers and computer parts. Since 2011, more than 1800 e-waste collection spots have been created and more than 230,000 tonnes of TV and computer waste has been collected. This scheme has diverted hazardous materials away from landfill and enabled the reuse of valuable resources contained in e-waste.
Parliament House Canberra ACT 2600 Telephone (02) 6277 7920

In addition, consumer affairs ministers from Australia and New Zealand agreed at a Consumer Affairs Forum on 30 August 2019 to consider laws to boost people's ability to repair their phones and other electronic goods. This agreement reflects a global movement towards a 'right to repair', which has grown in response to concerns about increasing amounts of waste going to landfill and design concepts like planned obsolescence.
Thank you for the opportunity to respond to the issues raised in this petition. I have copied this letter to the Assistant Treasurer, the Hon Michael Sukkar MP.
Yours sincerely
From the Minister for the Environment, Ms Sussan Ley(Petition No. EN0755)
Assange, Mr Julian
Dear Chair

Thank you for your letter of 5 August 2019, on behalf of the Standing Committee on Petitions, regarding Mr Julian Assange (petition number EN0757). Unfortunately, we have no record of receiving your predecessor's letter of 18 February 2019.

The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT) has either provided or offered consular assistance to Mr Assange on more than 100 occasions since 2010. This assistance remains available to Mr Assange should he choose to take it up. The offer of assistance was most recently reiterated in August 2019 via HMP Belmarsh Prison where Mr Assange is incarcerated. The nature of the assistance available is set out in the Consular Services Charter, a copy of which I enclose for your reference.

As outlined in the Charter, the Australian Government cannot intervene in the legal process of another country, just as we would not tolerate another country seeking to do so in Australia. Mr Assange has legal representation. He has been charged and sentenced for breaching bail conditions in the United Kingdom and he remains under investigation in relation to rape allegations in Sweden. He is also subject to a United States extradition request.

The Government is not aware of any grounds supporting the notion that Mr Assange will not receive due process in any legal proceedings that may be brought against him in the United Kingdom, the United States or Sweden. We are also confident that Mr Assange being treated appropriately in Belmarsh Prison.

2
Mr Assange has been issued with an Australian passport and should his outstanding legal matters be resolved, he will be free to return to Australia, just as any Australian can in such circumstances.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Payne(Petition No. EN0757)
General Practice
Dear Chair

I refer to the letter of 5 April 2019 from Mrs Lucy Wicks, MP, the former Chair of the Standing Committee on Petitions, concerning petition number EN0761âShortage of GPs in rural, remote and regional locations - Stronger Rural Health Strategy (Strategy). I regret the delay in responding.

The Strategy is a $550 million investment over five years that will deliver lasting improvements, including around 3,000 additional specialist GPs over the next ten years. The package of measures has been carefully crafted to influence change in an integrated way. it also balances initiatives that will come to fruition in the longer term with others offering more immediate benefits.

The Strategy will improve the capacity, quality, distribution and mix of our primary care workforce through a range of mechanisms that include: rural-based medical training (allowing medical students to undertake a majority of their training in rural settings); general practice training arrangements; increased Medicare benefits; financial incentives; reformed bonding arrangements; and Australia's skilled migration program.

The Australian Government appreciates the concern about the possible impact of the cessation of the Rural Other Medical Practitioners (ROMPs) Program, given that many GPs servicing rural areas are non-vocationally recognised. The Strategy ensures, however, that any impact will be marginal and outweighed by the benefits of other measures.

The unstructured ROMPs Program had the perverse effect of contributing to rural communities having less access to fully qualified GPs. New support programs conducted by the two general practice colleges will promote more timely and successful Fellowship outcomes. Both programs target regional, rural and remote areas.

Government funding will subsidise up to 5,000 doctors to participate on either the Independent Pathway offered by the Australian College of Rural and Remote Medicine or the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners' new Practice Experience Program (PEP). These doctors will have access to the higher Medicare rebates.

Transitional arrangements will minimise any disruption. About 2,500 existing ROMPs participants are guaranteed access to the higher Medicare rebates until 30 June 2023, providing they continue to meet program guidelines. Further, while the new PEP comes fully on stream, doctors who pass an entrance test will be placed on a waiting list giving immediate access to the higher rebates.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health, Mr Greg Hunt(Petition No. EN0761)
Private Health Insurance
Dear Mr O'Brien

Thank you for your letter of 6 August 2019 concerning petition EN0811 which relates to Lifetime Health Cover (LHC). The Australian Government remains committed to a sustainable private health sector and LHC is an important measure to promote this outcome.

LHC was introduced in 2000, to encourage people to purchase private insurance for hospital cover earlier in life and to maintain this cover. This helps alleviate the pressure on private health insurance premiums that would be caused by younger and lower risk members either never getting or dropping private health insurance. This would leave an increasingly high risk and costly pool of privately insured people, and result in increased premiums for all policy holders. Data from the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority shows that LHC has been very effective in bringing people into private health insurance at an earlier age.

If a private health insurance hospital policy is not purchased within the 'required period' of time, the LHC loading (at a rate of two per cent for every year you are over the age of 30) is applied and remains in place for a continuous 10 year period, after which time the loading is removed.

People have a choice about whether to use the public or private systems according to their own circumstances. Private health insurance is not compulsory. All Australian residents, regardless of whether they hold private health insurance, are eligible to be treated free of charge as public patients under Medicare.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health, Mr Hunt(Petition No. EN0811)
Income Tax
Dear Mr O'Brien

Thank you for your correspondence of 18 February 2019 originally to directed to the Treasurer concerning petition number EN0814, for a lower personal income tax rate for fly-in fly-out (FIFO) workers. Your correspondence has been referred to me as I have responsibility for this matter. I apologise for the delay in responding.

Australia has a progressive personal income tax system, meaning people with higher taxable incomes pay more tax as a proportion of their income than people on lower incomes. This is based on the principle that each person should contribute to the cost of government services according to his or her ability to pay.

The amount of income tax that each individual pays on their taxable income is based on the marginal rates and thresholds, as well as any offsets or levies that they may be eligible for that either reduce or increase tax payable. A key principle of the Australian tax system is horizontal equity, meaning that taxpayers in similar circumstances will be treated in a similar way. For this reason, it would be unfair to impose a lower rate of income tax on FIFO workers compared with workers in other occupations or sectors of the economy.

The Australian Government has delivered further tax relief for hard-working Australians, including FIFO workers, as announced in the 2019-20 Budget. The additional tax relief is now law and will deliver a further $158 billion in tax relief by enhancing the Personal Income Tax Plan first announced in the 2018-19 Budget. As a result, low- and middle-income earners will keep more of what they earn. The Government's tax relief measures will help to support consumption growth, which will be good for the economy.

The Government has enhanced the low and middle income tax offset (LMITO) by increasing the base offset from $200 to $255 and the maximum benefit from $530 to $1,080. This provides tax relief of up to $1,080 for singles, or up to $2,160 for dual income families. The offset is available for the 2018-19, 2019-20, 2020-21 and 2021-22 income years. The enhanced LMITO will assist over 10 million Australians, with about 4.5 million taxpayers with incomes between $48,000 and $90,000 receiving the full benefit for 2018-19. Around 2.3 million Australians with taxable incomes less than $37,000 will receive an offset of up to $255.

This builds on the increase to the top threshold of the 32.5 per cent tax bracket from $87,000 to $90,000, which took effect from 1 July 2018. Eligible individuals would have already received this tax relief for the 2018-19 income year through pay-as-you-go withholding.

The Government will replace the LMITO from 1 July 2022 through changes to income tax thresholds and the Low Income Tax Offset (LITO) which will lock in the benefits of LMITO. The top threshold of the 19 per cent tax bracket will increase from $37,000 to $45,000 and the maximum amount of LITO will increase from $445 to $700. At the same time, the top threshold of the 32.5 per cent tax bracket will increase from $90,000 to $120,000 preventing around 1.8 million taxpayers from entering the 37 per cent tax bracket in 2022-23.
From 1 July 2024 the Government has legislated structural reforms to the tax system, abolishing the 37 per cent tax bracket completely and reducing the 32.5 per cent tax rate to 30 per cent.

At its completion in 2024-25, the enhanced Personal Income Tax Plan will deliver a simpler tax system with only three tax rates. Australians earning between $45,000 and $200,000 will face a marginal tax rate of 30 per cent. A projected 94 per cent of taxpayers will face a marginal tax rate of no higher than 30 per cent.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Housing and Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar(Petition No. EN0814)
Q Fever
Dear Chair

I refer to the letter of 18 February 2019 from the former Chair of the Standing Committee on Petitions, Mrs Lucy Wicks MP, concerning petition EN0815 regarding funding for a National Q Fever Vaccination Program and support to develop a next generation Q fever vaccine. I regret the delay in responding.

Q fever is a potentially serious disease and vaccination remains the best form of protection. The Australian Government subsidises Q fever vaccine production and supply to the Australian market through substantial funding to the only global manufacturer, Seqirus Australia Pty Ltd (Seqirus). This funding ensures those at a high risk of Q fever have access to a vaccine. Australia is the only country in the world that routinely uses the Q fever vaccine as part of its prevention efforts. The contract with Seqirus provides approximately $42 million per year in funding to ensure supply of Q fever vaccine, antivenoms and pandemic influenza vaccine.

Current funding arrangements will ensure all Australians have access to the Qfever skin test and vaccine until 2024. Without this government support, Seqirus would not produce these products, as they are not commercially viable due to the low quantities purchased.

There is no standardised price for the Q fever vaccine as it is not listed on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS). The cost to the consumer will vary depending on where the vaccine is administered, for example, whether provided through the public or private system, or through an occupational vaccination program.

The Government is a strong supporter of vaccination and provides free vaccines to eligible cohorts through the National Immunisation Program (NIP). Under the National Health Act 1953, the Government cannot consider funding a vaccine on the NIP unless it has been recommended by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC). To date, the PBAC has not received a submission for Q-Vax from Seqirus.
As a commercial entity, Seqirus would need to consider a number of clinical, financial and supply factors in making an application to the PBAC for listing Q-Vax on the NIP or the PBS.

Pharmaceutical companies are private businesses that make their own decisions about the pricing of their medicines and whether they will market them exclusively on the private market or apply for subsidisation through the PBS or the NIP. Should Seqirus make an application to the PBAC in seeking to list 0-Vax on the PBS and the P8AC makes a recommendation in favour of this, the Government will list the medicine as a matter of priority.

The Government supports the critical role of health and medical research in improving health outcomes and recognises the significant burden that diseases such as Cifever can place on individuals, their families and the community.

The Government provides grants of financial assistance to support health and medical research in improving the health and wellbeing of Australians though the National Health and Medical Research Council and the Medical Research Future Fund (MRFF). The MRFF was established to provide a sustainable source of funding for vital medical research over the medium to long term. Investment decisions are guided by the independent Australian Medical Research Advisory Board, based on priorities determined through extensive community and sector consultation. Importantly, the MRFF is additional and complementary to the National Health and Medical Research Council, the point of difference being the MRFF's focus on translational research.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health, Mr Hunt(Petition No. EN0815)
Banking and Financial Services
Dear Mr O'Brien

Thank you for your correspondence of 5 August 2019, originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning the introduction of a Bank Star RatingâPetition number: EN0839. Your correspondence has been referred to me as I have responsibility for this matter. I apologise for the delay in responding to you.

I can inform you that the Australian Government is taking action to empower Australians to make better choices when purchasing financial products. On 9 May 2018, the Government introduced legislation to enable Open Banking in Australia. Open Banking will require banks to grant open access to data on the products they offer, while giving customers the ability to direct their bank to securely share their banking data with whom they choose. This should lead to the development of comparison services able to provide tailored recommendations. This will also dramatically simplify the choices consumers face, and enable them to find better products to suit their needs. The ability to transfer data will also help to overcome the 'hassle factor' that sees customers stick with their current provider despite more competitive deals elsewhere.

To ensure the long term success of the regime, a phased implementation has been adopted. From 1 July 2019, the Big Four Banks have been required to publicly share product data about credit and debit cards, deposit accounts and transaction accounts. The Australian Competition & Consumer Commission (ACCC) and CSIRO's Data 61 will also launch a pilot program to test the performance, reliability and security of the Open Banking system.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Housing and Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar(Petition No. EN0839)
Climate Change
Dear Mr O'Brien
Thank you for your letter of 5 August 2019 concerning Petition EN0858 on geoengineering policy.

The Australian Government takes its primary advice on climate science from the Bureau of Meteorology (BoM) and the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO). This advice aligns with information provided by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change and other organisations, such as the Australian Academy of Science, the World Meteorological Organization, the National Academy of Sciences and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. These world leading scientific organisations have found that the Earth's climate is changing and humans are primarily responsible. This finding is informed by long-term observations of air temperatures, the heat content of the ocean, changes to glaciers, ice sheets and sea ice.
If required, Commonwealth science agencies such as the BoM and the CSIRO could provide information on proposed interventions in the climate system, often referred to as `geoengineering.'

Under the Paris Agreement the Government has committed to reducing emissions by 26 to 28 per cent below 2005 levels by 2030. While Australia is only responsible for 1.3 per cent of global emissions, countries that each produce under 2 per cent of the world's emissions together account for around 40 per cent of global emissions. Our national target is achievable, balanced and responsible, and is part of coordinated global action to deliver a healthy environment for future generations, while keeping our economy strong.
The Government has a comprehensive set of policies to meet our emissions reduction commitments, encourage innovation and expand the clean energy sector.
Thank you for raising this matter with me.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the Environment, Ms Ley(Petition No. EN0858)
Banking and Financial Services
Dear Mr O'Brien

Thank you for the correspondence from the then Chair of the Standing Committee on Petitions, the Hon Lucy Wicks MP, originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning Petition EN0862. The original correspondence has been referred to me as I have responsibility for this matter.

The Government has agreed to take action on all 76 recommendations made by Commissioner Hayne. In doing so, we have recognised the contribution the mortgage braking sector makes to competition and the valuable service it provides to many Australians.

Mortgage brokers provide consumers with more choice when it comes to obtaining a mortgage and support smaller lenders who are otherwise unable to compete with the big banks. The Government wants more mortgage brokers, not less. We want to work in partnership with the sector to make it stronger, not weaker. That is why we have decided not to prohibit trail commissions on new loans as recommended by Commissioner Hayne but rather review their operation in three years' time.

This review will follow the introduction of a number of new measures the Government has already announced including: a best interests duty that will legally require mortgage brokers to act in the best interests of consumers; a new requirement that the value of upfront commissions be linked to the amount drawn-down by borrowers; a ban on campaign and volume-based commissions; and a two year limit on claw-back, starting from 1 July 2020.
The Government is confident that these changes will address conflicts of interest in the industry by better aligning the interests of consumers and mortgage brokers.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Superannuation, Financial Services and Financial Technology, Senator Hume(Petition No. EN0862)
Foreign Investment
Dear Mr O'Brien

Thank you for your correspondence of 29 July 2019, originally directed to the Treasurer, regarding the sale of Australian land - Petition number EN0877. Your correspondence has been referred to me as I have responsibility for this matter. I apologise for the delay in responding to you.

Foreign investment brings many benefits to Australia. It supports existing jobs and creates new jobs, encourages innovation and the induction of new technologies and skills, provides access to markets, and promotes competition amongst our industries. However, the Australian Government also recognises that foreign ownership of certain Australian assets may raise community concerns.

As such, the Government maintains a robust foreign investment screening regime to ensure that acquisitions of Australian land, or other Australian assets, by foreign persons is not contrary to the national interest. As part of this regime, the Government screens all proposed foreign investment transactions (above certain monetary thresholds) on a case-by-case basis, and has the ability to prohibit a transaction from occurring if it is likely to be contrary to our national interest.

Where an acquisition of Australian land is not prohibited, the Government's policies are also further designed to promote Australian interests. For example, a foreign person is generally prohibited from buying Australian agricultural land, unless Australians had also been offered an equal opportunity to purchase that land. Similarly, where a foreign person seeks to acquire an interest in residential land, the Government's policy is to channel that investment into new dwellings, rather than established dwellings, as this creates additional jobs in the construction industry, can increase government revenues, and increases Australia's housing stock.

Further information on Australia's foreign investment regime, including how it relates to acquisitions of Australian land, can be found on the Foreign Investment Review Board website at: www.firb.gov.au.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
From the Minister for Housing and Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar(Petition No. EN0877)
Child Care
Dear Mr O'Brien
Thank you for your letter of 29 July 2019 about Petition EN0884 regarding Australian Government support for informal kinship carers.

The Government acknowledges the importance of ensuring children and young people are safe and well and values the important contribution of kinship carers who provide loving homes for children who are unable to live with their parents. Kinship carers face many challenges, especially those who are caring for children outside the state or territory statutory care and protection system.

The petitioners call for the Government to abolish "informal care" nationally and to have one national law to provide consistency across states and territories. In Australia, state and territory governments have responsibility for the statutory care and protection of children and young people experiencing, or at risk of, abuse or neglect, including the child protection and out-of-home care systems. Each jurisdiction has its own legislation, policies and practices that govern who is a formal or informal carer and the support provided to carers.

Kinship carers are eligible for the full range of Australian Government family assistance payments such as Family Tax Benefit, Parenting Payment, Child Care Subsidy and the Foster Child Health Care Card to help with the costs of raising children.

The petitioners request a Royal Commission into kinship care nationwide. They may be interested to know that the Senate Community Affairs References Committee held an inquiry into grandparents who take primary responsibility for raising their grandchildren in 2013 and another into out-of-home care in 2015.

A number of the recommendations of the inquiry into out-of-home care are being addressed through the National Framework for Protecting Australia 's Children 2009-2020(the National Framework). The National Framework provides the critical foundation for governments and non-government organisations to work together to achieve our shared vision that Australia's children and young people are safe and well.

Improving stability and permanency for children in out-of-home care was a major theme of the inquiry's recommendations and is a priority under the Fourth Action Plan 2018-2020 of the National Framework.

The petitioners request the redevelopment of generic forms to take into account their unique circumstances and for easy access to allowances. Kinship carers, both formal and informal, may find the Grandparent Adviser program useful in navigating the support options available for their situation. Grandparent Advisers are available to all non-parent carers.

Based in the Department of Human Services (DHS), Grandparent Advisers provide support, advice and assistance to non-parent carers accessing government payments and services. Advisers also provide referrals to other community services providers.
Grandparent Advisers can be contacted via DHS on 1800 245 956. More information can be found at www.humanservices.gov.au/customer/services/centrelink/grandparent-advisers.

The Department of Social Services (DSS) also funds a range of services for any individual caring for a child, including kinship carers in a formal or informal caring role. These include peer support groups, playgroups and educational resources. Carers can use the search function at the DSS Grants Service Directory (www.serviceproviders.dss.gov.au/) to identify relevant services within their area.

The DSS-funded Raising Children Network website provides a complete resource for Australian parents and carers. It provides evidence-based information about raising children and caring for oneself as a parent or carer. The section on grandparent and kinship carers at www.raisingchildren.netau/grandparent_carers/being_a_grandparent_carer.html provides articles, videos and the opportunity to take part in grandparent and kinship carer forums.

The Australian Government will continue to provide national leadership and drive work with state and territory governments to deliver concrete actions to improve outcomes for some of Australia's most vulnerable children.
I trust the information provided will be of assistance to the petitioners.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Families and Social Services, Senator Ruston(Petition No. EN0884)
Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987
Dear Mr O'Brien
I refer to your letter of 29 July 2019 regarding petition number EN0893 concerning amendments to section 8 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987.

Section 8 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act provides that a House of the Parliament does not have power to expel a member from membership of a House. The petitioner's proposal seeks to enable a House to expel members where a House is 'acting in accordance with the freely expressed will of the people as determined by such method as deemed acceptable to the parliament', such as an electronic petition.

I am conscious that in responding to the petitioner's reform proposals that neither I nor officers of my department provide legal advice to parliamentary committees or to members of the public. However, the following general comments may be of assistance.

The Government is not proposing any change to section 8 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act. The composition of parliament is determined by the Australian people at regular elections. This was acknowledged by the Joint Select Committee on Parliamentary Privilege in its report of October 1984 which recommended the abolition of the power of the Houses to expel their members (at para 7.96):
... it is for the electors, not Members, to decide on the composition of Parliament.

Our system of representative democracy is enshrined in the Constitution. Sections 7 and 24 provide that members of Parliament are 'directly chosen by the people'. The grounds for disqualification of a member are set out in section 44 of the Constitution.

The House of Representatives and the Senate respond to disorderly conduct under the relevant standing orders, which provide for suspensions. For example, standing orders 203 and 204 of the Senate enable the suspension of a senator who has committed an offence for up to 14 sitting days. An offence is defined in standing order 203(1) as follows:
203 Infringement of order
1.If a senator:
(a) persistently and wilfully obstructs the business of the Senate;
(b) is guilty of disorderly conduct;
(c) uses objectionable words, and refuses to withdraw such words;
(d) persistently and wilfully refuses to conform to the standing orders; or
(e) persistently and wilfully disregards the authority of the chair, the President may report to the Senate that the senator has committed an offence.
A senator who wilfully disobeys an order of the Senate may be ordered to attend the Senate and may be taken into custody (Senate standing order 206).
Thank you for bringing the petitioner's concerns to my attention. Ihope this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Mr Porter(Petition No. EN0893)
Fair Work Act 2009
Dear Mr O'Brien
Thank you for your correspondence of 29 July 2019, concerning petition EN0902 to change the Fair Work Act 2009 (Fair Work Act) to include 'high income' employees.

The Fair Work Act, including the National Employment Standards, modern awards and the national minimum wage, provides a safety net of entitlements for national system employees. Fair Work Act coverage, including the National Employment Standards, is not based on the employee's income level, an employee is covered if their employer is a national system employer. The National Employment Standards include an entitlement to maternity leave.

Some employees are not covered by modern awards due to the nature and seniority of their role, and the unfair dismissal provisions of the Fair Work Act have an income test, but that does not exempt them from the Fair Work Act in general or the National Employment Standards.

The general protections provisions in the Fair Work Act prohibit adverse action (including dismissal and loss of shifts) by an employer against its employees for discriminatory reasons, including disability, sex, age, family or carer's responsibilities, and pregnancy. It is also unlawful to take adverse action against an employee because of the employee's workplace rights. These protections also apply to prospective employees and apply regardless of an employee's income level.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention, and I trust this information is of assistance to the petitioners.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Mr Porter(Petition No. EN0902)
Infrastructure: Bradfield Scheme
Dear Chair
Thank you for your letter of 8 August 2019 and the opportunity to respond to Petition EN0904 presented to the House of Representatives on 29 July 2019.

I am pleased to advise that the Australian Government will establish the National Water Grid Authority (the Authority), which was announced during the election campaign. As part of its work, the Authority will consider options for developing large-scale water capture and transfer schemes, such as elements of the Bradfield Scheme or hybrid versions of the Bradfield Scheme, to capture and transport rainwater to grow our agricultural sector, to improve stock and domestic supply, and for flood mitigation and drought proofing.

The Authority will deliver on the Government's commitment to invest $100 million to bring together world-best science and identify opportunities to increase water supply and reliability. The Government is committed to the sustainable development of Australia's water resources and integrating our water infrastructure to support the growth of regional Australia and meet the demands of a growing population.

The Authority will lead a robust and science-based assessment of Australia's water resources to identify real opportunities where new water infrastructure can be built. It will look to harvest unallocated water resources that can increase the capacity, connectivity and resilience of Australia's water storage and supply infrastructure.

In addition, the Authority will work in partnership with state and territory governments to develop a national pipeline of strategic water infrastructure initiatives to enhance water security and help make Australia's water supply more resilient during periods of drought.

In establishing the Authority, the Australian Government is providing national leadership to plan for and meet the water needs of our fanners, businesses and regional communities and to secure the future prosperity of all Australians.
Thank you again for your correspondence and I trust this is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
From the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr McCormack(Petition No. EN0904)
Indigenous Australians
Dear Chair

Thank you for your representations of 9 September 2019 concerning petition EN0923. The petitioners requested the Australian Government consider a new way of governance and expenditure for Indigenous Australians, both at the national and state and territory level.

In relation to the request to establish Indigenous governing bodies for each state and territory. The Australian Constitution clarifies the roles and responsibilities of the federal, state and territory levels, including the right to self-govern. As such, consideration of establishing a body at the state or territory level, as requested by the petitioners, is a matter for that jurisdiction.

The Morrison Government recognises that Indigenous Australians want their voices heard at all levels of governmentâlocal, state and federal. The Government is continuing to take steps to ensure there is greater representation of Indigenous voices at all levels of decision making. In conjunction with states, territories and community, a model for a local, regional and national 'voice' will be developed through a co-design process.

In order to progress this important work, the Government has allocated $7.3 million for co-design of models to improve local and regional decision-making and develop options for constitutional recognition. I acknowledge there are many views on this, including the ideas put forward in the petition. By listening to Elders, families and communities, we can drive practical, locally-led change, and I look forward to a range of ideas being explored through the co-design process.

As the Minister for Indigenous Australians, I have undertaken to listen to all views, and will not pre-empt the process and outcomes of the discussions we will be having over the coming months. The Government is committed to having these discussions with Indigenous people and the broader Australian community, to represent the diversity of views held.
Further, the Government is committed to recognising Indigenous Australians in the Constitution. Constitutional recognition is too important to get wrong and too important to rush.
We will work together with the community and Parliament to develop and bring forward a consensus option, in this term of Parliament, for the constitutional recognition of Indigenous Australians.
Thank you for raising this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Indigenous Australians, Mr Wyatt(Petition No. EN0923)
Political Parties: Campaign Policies
Dear Mr O'Brien

Thank you for your letter dated 9 September 2019, referring petition number EN0929 to me as the Minister responsible for electoral policy. The petition advocates the creation of a public register of political party positions.

In recent years, successful reforms to Australia's electoral system have followed work conducted by the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. The Committee is able to consider issues raised in public submissions across a broad range of connected topics, including issues like those raised in your letter. I encourage the petitioners to engage with the Committee with respect to the issues raised. Further information can be found at: www.aph.gov.au/Parliamentary_Business/Committees/Joint/Electoral_Matters.

The Government is committed to transparency. It is incumbent on individual parties and candidates to communicate with Australian voters. Action by any Government in this regard may be seen as potentially seeking to influence the election process.

There are, however, existing mechanisms that allow citizens to track political commitments and policies. For example, the Parliamentary Budget Office publishes a report after each election that shows the budget implications of the election commitments made by each of the major parties. This report shows the fiscal cost of each individual commitment and the aggregate impact of the commitments taken together.

The purpose of this report is to provide transparency around the fiscal impact of election commitments. From the next general election onwards, this report will include the medium-term (10 year) impact of all election commitments and minor parties will be able to have their commitments included in the report if they so choose.

On top of this, the Australian Government Budget Papers provide a picture of Australia's forecast financial performance and the government's fiscal policy for the forward years. The Budget includes estimates of Government revenue and expenses over a specified period. These papers are available for public scrutiny.

More broadly, the Australian Parliament House website provides a wide collection of information on the speeches and voting records of elected officials, as well as current legislation and parliamentary committees. This information can be found at: https://www.aph.gov.au/
Thank you for bringing the concerns referred to in the petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Finance, Senator Cormann(Petition No. EN0929)
Commonwealth Electoral System
Dear Mr O'Brien
Thank you for your letter dated 9 September 2019, referring petition number EN0932 to the Assistant Minister for Finance, Charities and Electoral Matters.

The Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters (JSCEM) is currently inquiring into all aspects of the conduct of the 2019 Federal Election and related matters. It would be within the scope of this inquiry to consider the merits of amending preference arrangements in House of Representatives elections, which the petitioners have proposed.

I would therefore encourage all petitioners to raise their concerns with JSCEM. Contact details for the Committee can be found at: www.aph.gov.au/Parliamentary_Business/Committees/Joint/Electoral Matters
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention.
Kind regards
from the Minister for Finance, Senator Cormann(Petition No. EN0932)
Climate Change
Dear Mr O'Brien
Thank you for your letter of 9 September 2019 concerning Petition EN0933 about a ban on the use of unsustainable resources.
The Australian Government is working across a broad range of areas to support the sustainable use of resources. To give a few examples:
The Australian, state and territory governments are working together to reduce waste and improve recycling, including by banning the export of waste plastic, paper, glass and tyres.
The Government's $1 billion National Landcare Program is protecting the environment and supporting sustainable agricultural production.
The Government is working with state and territory governments to develop a new
national framework to manage the environmental risks of industrial chemicals.
The Government regulates activities that may have a significant impact on matters of environmental significance under federal environmental laws.
The Government is working to reduce Australia's greenhouse gas emissions, in line with our international commitments, through support for energy efficiency and renewable energy, among other things.

It is through measures such as these, as well as consumers choosing to make more sustainable choices, that we can achieve sustainable resource use. A ban on unsustainable use, while conceptually appealing, would be difficult, if not impossible, to apply in practice. For example, it would require defining what is sustainable and being able to consistently and objectively measure the sustainability of millions of products.
Thank you again for the opportunity to respond to the matters raised in this petition.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the Environment, Ms Ley(Petition No. EN0933)
Commonwealth Electoral System
Dear Mr O'Brien

Thank you for your letter dated 9 September 2019, referring petition number EN0946 to Senator the Hon Zed Seselja, Assistant Minister for Finance, Charities and Electoral Matters. As the Minister responsible for electoral policy, the matter has been referred to me for response. The petition requested that our democracy include elements of Direct Democracy in the form of recall elections and initiatives that allow citizens to directly participate in policy decisions. I respond to the petition's request below.

Australia is a representative democracy in the Westminster traditionâeligible electors vote for candidates to carry out the business of governing on their behalf. The commitment to representative government is embedded in the Australian Constitution, which provides that both houses of the Federal Parliament are to be 'directly chosen by the people' (sections 7 and 24).

There are mechanisms within our representative model of government that allow direct citizen participation in law making and policy review. For example, parliamentary committees, such as the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters (JSCEM), provide a channel for communication between parliament and the public that encourages greater community participation in the parliamentary process.

Where considered necessary and/or appropriate the Government can seek the views of the nation outside of an election context. The Australian Government's Postal Marriage Law Survey (the Survey) held from 12 September to 7 November 2017, and the three national plebiscitesâtwo on the conscription of troops during World War 1 and one on a national song in 1977âare examples.

The Government has no plans to alter the electoral system to allow for recall elections. Fundamental changes to our elections such as those proposed in this petition are often considered by the JSCEM and developed with cross-party support, so they can be enacted. Accordingly, the petitioners may wish to approach the JSCEM with their ideas.
Thank you for bringing the concerns referred to in the petition to my attention.
I have copied this letter to the Assistant Minister for Finance, Charities and Electoral Matters.
Kind regards
from the Minister for Finance, Senator Cormann(Petition No. EN0946)
Members of Parliament: Allegiance
Dear Mr O'Brien

Thank you for your letter of 9 September 2019 regarding petition number EN0948, requesting clarification as to the status of the 'law and the Gospel of God' in Australia. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring these matters to my attention.

Neither I nor officers of my department provide legal advice to the public. It would therefore be inappropriate to comment on legal aspects raised in the petition. If the petitioners have concerns about any particular laws or have legal queries, they may wish to seek independent legal advice. However, the following general comments may be of assistance.

Australia is a democracy which respects the separation of church and state. Section 116 of the Constitution reflects this state of affairs. In broad terms, section 116 of the Constitution prevents the Commonwealth making laws for establishing any religion, imposing any religious observance or prohibiting the free exercise of religion. Nor can the Commonwealth pass a law requiring a 'religious test' for an office or public trust under the Commonwealth.

I note that section 116 does not prohibit action simply because it might be said, in one way or another, to relate to a religious organisation. In the case of Attorney-General (Vic); ex red Black v Commonwealth (1981) 146 CLR 559, for example, a challenge to Commonwealth grants for distribution among denominational schools was rejected.

As to the petitioners queries about the oath or affirmation of allegiance set out in the Schedule to the Constitution (see also section 42 of the Constitution), it may be of interest that the House of Representatives Practice (7th ed.) states that 'the oath of allegiance need not necessarily be made on the authorised version of the Bible, although this has been the common practice. A Member may recite the oath while holding another form of Christian holy book, or, in respect of a non-Christian faith, a book or work of such a nature. The essential requirement is that every Member taking an oath should take it in a manner which affects his or her conscience regardless of whether a holy book is used or not' (p 144)
Thank you for raising this matter with me.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Mr Porter (Petition No. EN0948)
Member for New England
Dear Mr O'Brien
I refer to your letter of 9 September 2019 regarding petition number EN0956.

The petition alleges that the Hon Barnaby Joyce MP falsely declared his eligibility for nomination for a federal election on six occasions. The petition asks the House of Representatives to refer the alleged conduct to the Australian Federal Police (AFP) and the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions (CDPP).

The AFP is responsible for investigating offences against the Criminal Code Act 1995. Any person may make a report to the AFP if they have evidence of any offence. The AFP operates independently of Government and the decision whether or not to investigate an alleged offence is a matter for the AFP's discretion.

The initiation and conduct of a prosecution is a matter for the CDPP to determine in accordance with the Prosecution Policy of the Commonwealth. Once sufficient evidence has been gathered to substantiate a criminal charge, this evidence is compiled in a brief and referred to the CDPP. The CDPP is an independent statutory authority operating outside the political process.
Thank you for raising this matter with me.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Mr Porter (Petition No. EN0956)
Climate Change
Dear Mr O'Brien

Thank you for your letter of 9 September 2019 to the Attorney-General, the Hon Christian Porter MP, concerning petition EN0961 about making ecocide an Australian criminal offence. Your letter has been referred to me as I am the minister responsible for the matters raised in the petition.

The Australian Government is committed to the highest environmental standards. Our central environmental law, the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 (EPBC Act), establishes a rigorous and transparent regulatory framework for protecting nationally important environmental matters, such as threatened species and World Heritage properties. The Government becomes involved where activities may have a significant impact on matters protected under the EPBC Act.

In recent years we have put in place measures to further improve our regulatory performance, including the establishment of an independent Office of Compliance that focuses on the investigation of environmental crimes and the increased use of 'strategic assessments', which allow us to consider environmental impacts and protection measures at a landscape scale. The Department of the Environment and Energy continues to work with stakeholders to increase their awareness of their responsibilities under national environmental law.

As you may be aware, an independent review of the EPBC Act is required to commence by October 2019. The review will involve extensive consultation and will consider all ideas put forward by industry, environment and community groups to improve and strengthen national environmental law.
Thank you for the opportunity to respond to the issues raised in the petition.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the Environment, Ms Ley(Petition No. EN0961)
Australian Constitution
Dear Mr O'Brien
Thank you for your letter of 13 August 2018 regarding petition number EN0969.

The current petition refers to my response to petition number EN0615. As I outlined in my response to that petition, the Australian Federal Police (AFP) is responsible for investigating offences against Commonwealth law. Should an investigation by the AFP reveal sufficient evidence, that evidence would be compiled in a brief and referred to the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions (CDPP).

It is not the CDPP's role to investigate offences, but rather, to decide whether to commence and carry out a prosecution. The initiation and conduct of a prosecution is a matter for the CDPP to determine in accordance with the Prosecution Policy of the Commonwealth. The CDPP is not obliged to prosecute every matter referred to it. Rather, it is for the CDPP to decideâin its discretionâwhether prosecution would be appropriate in the particular circumstances of each case.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Mr Porter (Petition No. EN0969)
Commonwealth Electoral Act
Dear Mr O'Brien

Thank you for your letter dated 9 September 2019, referring petition number EN0979 to Senator the Hon Zed Seselja, Assistant Minister for Finance, Charities and Electoral Matters. As the Minister responsible for electoral policy, the matter has been referred to me for response. The petition requested that a number of initiatives be taken up in preparation for the 2022 Federal election. I respond to each element of the petition's request below.

In terms of process that support voting, Electronic Certified Lists (ECLs), a digital database used to electronically check off a voter's name from a centralised electoral roll, have been used on a trial basis by the Australian Electoral Commission (AEC) since the 2013 Federal election. ECLs are being increasingly used by the AEC at all electoral events. The Government is working with the AEC to investigate the expanded use of polling place technology for future electoral events.

A person must provide proof of their identity when they enrol to vote.
